USC only has one problem and it's cultural. They recruit top tier talent, it shows up in flashes every season, but never consistently enough to gel into the team it should be.

The kind of high tier talent that goes to USC needs a coach they respect in football and life. Carroll was that dude, he did it in college and he did it in the NFL. That's the type of coach USC wants, problem being they generally leave and are hard to predict.

The alternative is to get the exact coach they won't hire. Someone boringly unsexy who doesn't care about the donors. Father figure, nose to grindstone, the kind of guy who will bench a WR for not blocking... and can pull it off without the lock room disintegrating.

There's no way to get kids into the sport.

In my many years of watching CFB, the annual Army-Navy game has meant nothing to me. It's a fun tradition featuring two teams nobody has any investment in. Considering the matchup's irrelevance, the game receives its own weekend to be played.

However, with the 12-team playoff, this game could become a playoff game. If each team goes undefeated (meaning they both beat Notre Dame and Navy beats Tulane), they will clearly be the two highest-ranked non-P4 schools. Having these two teams play in an AAC championship game Dec 6th without having played each other in the regular season, then the very next week play in an unfortunately irrelevant game eliminates what could prove to be the most fascinating and highly watched Army-Navy game in history.

There are several scenarios in which the Army-Navy game COULD have impacted the playoffs, but because of the timing, it won't.

Swimming has a little bit of a buffer because you can pool coaches between the men’s and women’s teams, and most of their facilities are shared either with the on-campus rec center or a city pool, lowering costs. 

Track gets a little bit of a buffer as well again because of the coach pooling, but also because you can squeeze three sports out of it (XC, Indoor, Outdoor). You do need two separate practice facilities, but you can get pretty far without having to host any competitions, so they don’t need a ton of amenities. 

Wrestling on an island by itself. Big roster with no obvious Title IX offset. Lots of travel compared to a Swim or Track season. Needs a standalone practice facility and since the season overlaps with MBB/WBB/VB/GYM, it may necessitate having a second competition facility as well. Bad combo all around.

And I get it, it can feel demeaning to know that your status as a collegiate athlete exists solely on the largesse of these revenue generating sports while your sport/program cannot sustain itself on its own virtues.

I've been involved in swimming my whole life, and I'm close with a bunch of top D1 program swimmers that I trained with during high school. Personally, nothing killed my hope more for the future of the sport than the fiasco Michigan State made when it decided to kill its mens and womens swim and dive programs back during covid. 

Alumni of the program and the wider swim community in Michigan rallied to save the program, raising $5.2 million, an incredible sum for a non-top swim and dive program, yet MSU still wouldn't bring it back, later adding a goal of $6.5 million. 

A couple of years, lawsuits, and Title IX violations later, there was a little bit of hope because MSU was going to build a new rec center with a 50 meter pool which would be a great opportunity to start the program again. The old pool was nearing the end of its life span and was due to be replaced anyways, and the money we raised could help support the program. In fact, in the interim, we even secured $8.5 million from two anonymous donors but MSU didn't accept it because they were estate bequests and endowments rather than "cash in hand."

Then, MSU says that in order to "upgrade" the pool to support a competitive varsity program (which keep in mind is already going to be build as part of a $200 million dollar rec center) we'd have to raise more money to make the upgrades.

The cost? **$26.5 million dollars**. That's enough money to support a program like MSU's for 30+ years. And the pool is being built anyways! We knew it was a bullshit number to kill our efforts, but we knew it would be insurmountable. 

  
*Sigh*. Point being, unless you're a top top program the people in charge don't care about sports like ours, and with the way NIL keeps going they're only going to get more giddy to cut programs. I'm not even sure how much leverage programs like cal, stanford, florida, texas, and virginia will have in the future despite producing so much of our Olympic swim team.
